definition:
A *sturdy number* is a positive integer $n$ having a given binary weight
(number of on bits, or instances of the digit 1 in its binary
representation) such that no multiple $mn$ (with $m$ being any positive
integer) has a lesser binary weight. For example, 10 is written 1010 in
binary; it has two on bits; any multiple of 10 has at least two on bits.

All powers of two corresponding to positive integer exponents are sturdy
numbers, since its representation can only have one on bit (the one
corresponding to the appropriate power of two), and multiplying by
another power of two gives yet another power of two, while multiplying
by any other integer gives a number with at least two on bits.

Likewise we can verify that integers having two on bits are also sturdy
numbers, since none of its multiples can be a power of two and therefore
any multiple must also have at least two on bits.

16, 17, 18, 20, 21, 24, 28, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 40, 42, 45, 48,

that it was only necessary to test up to $m = 14 \times 10^7$.
